hint.text: There are 2 arithmetic progressions which needs to be determined with the help of their first term and common difference.

solution.text:
distance between A to B is = 3.0
So for the first km Rohan will be charged \(a_1=5\)
and for the second km Rohan will be charged \(a_2=5+2=7\)
and for the third km Rohan will be charged \(a_3=5+\,2*2=9\)
Now distance between B to C is = 3.0
So for the 4th km Rohan will be charged \(b_1=8\)
and for the 5th km Rohan will be charged \(b_2=8+14 =22\)
and for the 6th km Rohan will be charged \(b_3=8+\,2*14=36\)
Total money spent = \(a_1+a_2+a_3+b_1+b_2+b_3 = 87\)

content.text:
Rohan wants to travel from point A to Point C via B.
B is at the midpoint of the 6 kilometers road joining A and C.
From A to B the only conveyance available is an auto rickshaw at a fare of Rs 5 for the first km and Rs 2 more than the previous km for each additional km.
From B to C the only conveyance available is an Ola Cab at a fare of Rs 8 for the first km and Rs 14 more than the previous km for each additional km.
.
Find the total money that Rohan spends on his travel?

solution.text:
Amount of water in the tank at 3 am is 100.0 litres
duration of outflow to be considered is \(6\,am-3\,am\,=3 hours\)
rate of discharge of water = \(20\,litres\,per\,hour\)
As the decrement in the amount of water is constant(d)= -\(20\)
so, the water in the tank after each hour will form an AP
The first term as \(a_1=100.0\,and\,d=-20\)
Now the water in the tank after 3 hours(n=4) is= \(a_1-3d\)
\(100.0-60=40.0\)

content.text:
A tank with a capacity of 200 litres is half filled with water.
At 3 am someone turns the outlet valve on
The water starts to spill out from the tank at a rate of 20 litres per hour.
How much water is left in the tank at 6 am.

hint.text: For any series to be in an Arithmetic progression the difference between two consecutive numbers should remain constant

solution.text:
We see that the Second term = a + d
\(a_2=(-11)\)
The third term = a + 2*d
\( a_3=(-17)\)
The 4th term = a + 3*d
\( a_4=(-23)\)

content.text: Calculate the first four terms of the AP, when the first term(a) is (-5) and the common difference(d) is (-6). From the options given below tick on the 4th term in your calculated list:

solution.text:
We see that the Second term = a + d
\(a_2=\frac{-68}{15}\)
The third term = a + 2*d
\( a_3=\frac{-86}{15}\)
The 4th term = a + 3*d
\( a_4=\frac{-104}{15}\)

content.text: Calculate the first four terms of the AP, when the first term(a) is \(\frac{-10}{3}\) and the common difference(d) is \(\frac{-6}{5}\). From the options given below tick on the 4th term in your calculated list:

hint.text: For any series to be in an Arithmetic progression the difference between two consecutive numbers should remain constant

solution.text:
We should have a constant difference
For a list calculate the difference of any 2 consecutive terms
\(a_2=14 \) and \( a_1=2\) we get \(d=12\)
for next numbers \(a_3=26\) and \(\,a_2=14\) we get \(d=12\)
The list is an AP when the difference of any two consecutive number is same, in the above case \(12\).

content.text: Which of the following list of numbers does form an AP?

solution.text:
amount of money deposited(p) = 200
compound interest(r) rate= 10% per year.
amount of money accumulated(A) after t years can be calculated by using, \(A=p*(1+(r*.01))^t\)
To find the first number of the list we take \(t=1\) and get \(220.0\)
To find the second number of the list we take \(t=2\) and get \(242.0\)
To find the third number of the list we take \(t=3\) and get \(266.2\)
By taking difference of the two consecutive terms of the list \(220.0,242.0,266.2\)
We clearly see that \(a_2-a_1\) is not equal to \(a_3-a_2\)
Therefore this list doesn't form an AP

content.text: Ram deposited Rs 200 at compound interest at 10 % per annum. If the money in the account every year is taken to form a list of numbers, does the list forms an arithmetic progression.
Verifying whether a list of numbers is an arithmetic progression series or not?

hint.text: For any series to be in an Arithmetic progression the difference between two consecutive numbers should remain constant

content.text: finding the common difference of any arithmetic series

hint.text: common difference is the difference between any 2 consecutive terms of the given series
